quotes: In 2005, Karman co-founded Women Journalists Without Chains, in order to promote freedom of expression and democratic rights.
In recognition of her non-violent struggle for democracy and advocacy for women’s rights in Yemen, Karman was awarded the 2011 Nobel Peace Prize.
See Tawakkol Karman at: 25 May - Forum of Experts

organizations.name: Women Journalists Without Chains
quotes: In 2005, Karman co-founded Women Journalists Without Chains, in order to promote freedom of expression and democratic rights.

organizations.name: Foreign Policy Magazine
quotes: She was listed among Foreign Policy Magazine’s Top 100 Global Thinkers and one of CNN’s most powerful women in the Arab world.

organizations.name: CNN
quotes: She was listed among Foreign Policy Magazine’s Top 100 Global Thinkers and one of CNN’s most powerful women in the Arab world.

organizations.name: TIME Magazine
quotes: TIME Magazine described her as a ‘Torchbearer of the Arab Spring’ and named her both one of the 100 most influential women defining the last century and one of the Most Rebellious Women in History.

roles.title: journalist and activist
quotes: As a journalist and activist in Yemen working under severe restrictions, she organised events and wrote on issues related to governance and injustice, corruption, extremism, terrorism, women’s rights, girls’ rights, early marriage, malnutrition, illiteracy, poverty and religious reforms.

roles.title: co-founder
quotes: In 2005, Karman co-founded Women Journalists Without Chains, in order to promote freedom of expression and democratic rights.

roles.title: leader of peaceful protests
quotes: During the Arab Spring, despite attempts on her life, Karman led peaceful protests in Yemen’s Capital Sana’a, which ended with the resignation of then-President Ali Salehi.

roles.title: Nobel Peace Prize laureate
quotes: In recognition of her non-violent struggle for democracy and advocacy for women’s rights in Yemen, Karman was awarded the 2011 Nobel Peace Prize.
for her work building a culture of non-violence in the Middle East and once called ‘The Mother of the Revolution.’

As a journalist and activist in Yemen working under severe restrictions, she organised events and wrote on issues related to governance and injustice, corruption, extremism, terrorism, women’s rights, girls’ rights, early marriage, malnutrition, illiteracy, poverty and religious reforms.
During the Arab Spring, despite attempts on her life, Karman led peaceful protests in Yemen’s Capital Sana’a, which ended with the resignation of then-President Ali Salehi.
Read more about the summit with videos of some of the key speakers, clips and panel discussions in Washington D.C.
